item.title: Covid: NHS warns of 'significant reduction' in vaccines
item.description: Local health organisations have been told to expect a reduction in vaccine supply at the end of March.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Football child sex abuse report finds 'institutional failings'
item.description: A long-awaited report into football's historical child sex abuse scandal finds "institutional failings" at the Football Association between 1995 and 2000 left some children unsafe.

item.title: Stuart Lubbock: Murder arrest over death in Michael Barrymore pool
item.description: The man is being held after the death of Stuart Lubbock at the presenter's home in 2001.

item.title: Piers Morgan's Meghan comments break Ofcom complaints record
item.description: More than 57,000 people complain over Morgan's remarks about Meghan on Good Morning Britain.

item.title: Health department was 'smoking ruin' on Covid - Cummings
item.description: The prime minister's former aide criticises the department over PPE and procurement at start of the pandemic.

item.title: 'Toxic culture of sexism' in police, says former police chief
item.description: A former chief constable says women reporting crimes endure "endless repeated humiliation".

item.title: Covid: EU plans rollout of travel certificate before summer
item.description: It will permit travel by those vaccinated, or who have tested negative or recently recovered.

item.title: Atlanta shootings: Spa shooting victims identified after arrest
item.description: Investigators say the suspect admitted to the attack, but denied that he was motivated by racism.

item.title: St Patrick's Day: Police clear crowds at Belfast's Botanic Gardens
item.description: Police were called on Wednesday after young people gathered in Botanic Gardens in south Belfast.

item.title: Social care leaders warn of funding 'cliff edge'
item.description: With emergency pandemic funding to end in two weeks, care organisations voice long-term cash fears.

item.title: Former Top Gear presenter Sabine Schmitz dies aged 51
item.description: Former racing driver and Top Gear presenter Sabine Schmitz has died from cancer aged 51.

item.title: Local traffic changes 'more divisive than Brexit'
item.description: The schemes were introduced to tackle increasing traffic on minor roads but some face fierce opposition.

item.title: St Patrick's Day: Countries celebrate Ireland's patron saint
item.description: Online events are taking the place of traditional parades due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Sir David Attenborough answers dinosaur query from Otis, 4
item.description: Four-year-old Otis's mum was stumped, so they wrote to Sir David Attenborough... and he replied.

item.title: Syria: The scars left by a school bombing
item.description: BBC cameraman Darren Conway has returned to Syria to meet survivors of the Iqra school bombing, the aftermath of which he filmed in 2013.

item.title: Double mastectomy: 'I lost a large part of my identity'
item.description: A social media personality has created a video about her BRCA2 gene test and upcoming surgery.

item.title: Photography project gets behind the lens with Pat, Paddy and Patrick
item.description: A photography project is capturing the stories of people named Paddy, Pat, Patrick or Padraig.

item.title: Michaela Coel's 'electrifying' I May Destroy You wins at RTS Awards
item.description: Michaela Coel's acclaimed drama is among the shows honoured by the Royal Television Society.

item.title: Infertility: 'Women need to hear ‘you are not alone’'
item.description: In the US, one in eight couples experience infertility. But a culture of silence and stigma means most people suffer alone.

item.title: 'The Gospel Truth?' Covid-19 vaccines and the danger of religious misinformation
item.description: Many religious leaders are spreading the word that vaccines are safe and effective, but some are undermining that message.

item.title: Iceland shaken by more than 50,000 earthquakes in three weeks
item.description: Geologist Helga Torfadottir takes a BBC team to an active volcano area.

item.title: Covid lockdown a year on: 'My dad became my best friend'
item.description: Shireen admits she "didn't really care" about her dad, until lockdown brought them closer than ever.

item.title: Lions at Denver Zoo frolic in the snow after historic blizzard
item.description: These cats enjoyed the record snowfall that hit Colorado over the weekend.

item.title: Covid in Europe: Vaccine suspension hits rollout as cases rise
item.description: As several countries pause the AstraZeneca jab, six reporters explain what is happening across Europe.

item.title: When is the census and what is it for?
item.description: The once-a-decade survey gives a snapshot of UK life and helps find out what services are needed.

item.title: Uber minimum wage 'will make a difference'
item.description: Some drivers welcome Uber concessions on pay and pensions, but others said it made no difference.

item.title: Cheltenham Festival: 'I gambled £50,000 on a horse and lost everything'
item.description: A former teacher and cricketer is talking about his gambling addiction to help warn others.

item.title: The coffee start-ups brewing up a storm in lockdown
item.description: The pandemic has hit coffee shop chains hard, but some smaller businesses are thriving.

item.title: Festivals 2021: Which ones are still going ahead?
item.description: Glastonbury has had to cancel, Reading & Leeds is going ahead. What about the rest?

item.title: LGBT rights: New threat for Poland's 'rainbow families'
item.description: A new law aims to close a loophole that is the only remaining way for LGBT people to adopt children.

item.title: US-China relations: Beyond the 'Cold War' cliche
item.description: A look at the tensions between the superpowers as delegates gather for a meeting in Alaska.

item.title: Integrated Review: Fact-checking claims about the Army, aid and nuclear weapons
item.description: MPs debating the government's defence review made claims on army funding, international aid and nuclear weapons.

item.title: Bitcoin: Fake Elon Musk giveaway scam 'cost man £400,000'
item.description: A German man lost 10 Bitcoin to so-called giveaway scammers on Twitter and experts say scams are rising.

item.title: Zack Snyder's Justice League: A 'vindication' of director's vision, say critics
item.description: The director's reworked cut arrives on Thursday - and most say it's an improvement on the original.

item.title: So you want a career in building computer games?
item.description: A career in computer games can be rewarding but tough to get into.

item.title: Covid lockdown: Charities warn cancer death rate could rise
item.description: Nearly 50 cancer charities send a stark warning about the impact Covid-19 has had on UK cancer care.

item.title: 'Just a legend' - Tiger Roll claims fifth Cheltenham Festival win
item.description: Tiger Roll claims a fifth Cheltenham Festival win while Put The Kettle On lands the Champion Chase.

item.title: 'Curry is a special, special player - he could be another McCaw'
item.description: England flanker Tom Curry could develop into a player to match All Black great Richie McCaw, says forwards coach Matt Proudfoot.

item.title: Punter needs one more Cheltenham Festival winner to earn £511,000 from a £5 accumulator
item.description: A punter needs Marsh Novices' Chase favourite Envoi Allen to win to land £511,000 from a £5 bet on the third day of the Cheltenham Festival.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: How many people have had their vaccine in the UK?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 24 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: When will pubs, gyms and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the test-and-trace system work?
item.description: MPs have said the government's test-and-trace system is too expensive and hasn't helped fight the pandemic.

item.title: Does the Oxford vaccine have a blood clot problem? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: A growing number of travel companies are insisting that passengers will need to be vaccinated to travel.

item.title: What are the Brazil, South Africa and UK variants and will vaccines work?
item.description: More cases are being found in the UK, including a variant first seen in Brazil.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: What happens if I don't get the Covid vaccine?
item.description: There are multiple coronavirus vaccines being rolled out in countries across the UK and around the world. What happens if you don't want it?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of new variants of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus testing: How to do a lateral flow test at home
item.description: Coronavirus lateral flow tests are free and provide a quick result within 30 minutes. But how do you do one?

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.
